There is no support plan in the SkyWalking community. Anyone wants to add new plugin, we are welcome the contribution and be happy to help with review. But no committer will be responsible to provide a new one, unless he needs it by himself.
So cool. I want to try it, but I'm not sure I can handle it.

> So cool. I want to try it, but I'm not sure I can handle it.

You need to understand how current topology generated from trace raw data. This is not an easy task. This enhancement could be a separated release from my understanding. I would say 6.6.0 or 6.7.0 should for this, before the end of this year, as a closure and super powerful feature of SkyWalking 2019.

Test fails. Please recheck.
This depends on your network strategy. Different companies have different requirements.
@aderm I think you miss your test case change? CI fails.
yes, unit test is very useful.

When I changed the codes to insert more data, interesting things happened.
I inserted 1200 records to 2000 size queu for both
```
for (int i = 0; i < 1200; i++) {
            buffer1/buffer2.save(new Object());
        }
```

```
Benchmark                                 Mode  Cnt      Score     Error  Units
ChannelWritePerformanceTest.testBuffer1  thrpt   10  30516.424 Â± 745.733  ops/s
ChannelWritePerformanceTest.testBuffer2  thrpt   10  33467.919 Â± 384.183  ops/s
```
Please use the prototype script to generate the test project skeleton. We have added them to the documentation.

As @yantaowu told me offline, they are using `Queue#offer` with accepting queue is full and data lost tradeoff. The result is not so different, as we don't make the queue full in our tests. **testBuffer2** is using `#offer` method in the test.
```
Benchmark                                 Mode  Cnt      Score      Error  Units
ChannelWritePerformanceTest.testBuffer1  thrpt   10  29020.969 Â±  613.798  ops/s
ChannelWritePerformanceTest.testBuffer2  thrpt   10  32102.383 Â± 1715.402  ops/s
```

I dig more into the ArrayBlockingQueue source code, I noticed there is a misguide from the user feedback. `ArrayBlockingQueue` didn't ever deal with across thread visibility ever. Everyone here could check the source code. 

So after I remove the `volatile`, but keep the `BufferItem`. There is no advantage of the BlockingQueue.
```
Benchmark                                 Mode  Cnt      Score      Error  Units
ChannelWritePerformanceTest.testBuffer1  thrpt   10  45184.551 Â±  425.330  ops/s
ChannelWritePerformanceTest.testBuffer2  thrpt   10  33548.799 Â± 1793.056  ops/s
```

Furthermore, by using the master codes of DataCarrier, we have much higher throughput. The following result is using the master code as `testBuffer1`.
```
Benchmark                                 Mode  Cnt      Score      Error  Units
ChannelWritePerformanceTest.testBuffer1  thrpt   10  47261.798 Â± 2850.445  ops/s
ChannelWritePerformanceTest.testBuffer2  thrpt   10  34402.022 Â±  356.511  ops/s
```

For following all these tests, unless we have very specific evidence showing there is across threads visibility issue, I think we should close this PR for now. 

1. Visibility is not provided in BlockingQueue, it provides a global lock, which allows lower traffic.
1. Adding it could cost more CPU, but without evidence, we should not change this.

This seems like multiple segments, rather than multiple spans. Right?

Right now it is not ordered from my understanding. We may need to add them by start time.
`TraceQueryService#findRoots` should order the return list, by start time.
